conclusion: Apply principles of mechanics, Newton's laws of motion, and concept of friction.
Four identical wooden blocks on a smooth horizontal surface; blocks B and C connected by a light spring; force F applied to block B.
Blocks accelerate together with the same acceleration.
Identify forces: applied force F and frictional force on each block.
Spring compresses when block B accelerates, exerting opposing force on block C.
Net force on each block must be the same due to same acceleration.
Sum of applied force F and frictional force on block D equals sum of forces on blocks B and C.
Using Newton's second law: F = ma; frictional force on block D equals sum of frictional forces on blocks B and C.
Frictional force on block D is equal to frictional force on block C.
Magnitude of static friction force on block D equals magnitude of frictional force on block C.
